awd_titl_txt: Spatial Location and Biogeochemical Drivers of Mercury Methylation and Demethylation in the Rice Rhizosphere
awd_abstract_narration:
Rice, a staple food of more than four billion people, can serve as a primary route of human exposure to methylmercury (MeHg). Methylmercury bioaccumulates in organisms and is highly neurotoxic. Even at trace levels, MeHg adversely affects human health. By contrast, inorganic mercury is less bioavailable and does not bioaccumulate. Thus, MeHg contamination of rice is a global public health concern. The MeHg content of rice grain originates from the paddy soil, where it is taken up by rice roots and transported to the developing grain. All soils contain inorganic mercury derived from natural, as well as modern and historical anthropogenic sources. The MeHg in paddy soil is produced by aquatic microorganisms from this inorganic mercury, a process known as methylation. Another suite of microorganisms transform MeHg back into inorganic mercury, termed demethylation. The availability of MeHg for plant uptake depends on the relative rates of methylation and demethylation in the soil zone surrounding rice roots, an area called the rice rhizosphere. The roots of rice plants release both oxygen and organic carbon into rhizosphere soil. The supply of both organic carbon and oxygen can modulate methylation and demethylation. This project is clarifying how plant inputs of oxygen and organic carbon affect rates of methylation and demethylation and thus alter rhizosphere MeHg concentrations. Results can inform agricultural strategies to minimize MeHg contamination of rice grain. For example, findings may guide selection of rice cultivars that release oxygen and carbon in amounts and proportions that favor demethylation over methylation. Project personnel will disseminate results to K-12 students, laypeople, policymakers, and rice growers by creating an artistic, high-quality video that presents health hazards of MeHg in rice and other foods, introduces the complex MeHg cycle, and discusses strategies for minimizing MeHg production in rice paddies. 

The project combines experimental manipulations of root exudates and soil oxygenation with mercury isotope speciation methods and two-dimensional, real-time visualizations of rhizosphere oxygen concentrations to test hypotheses about how carbon and oxygen influence rates and spatial occurrence of methylation and demethylation within paddy soil. During peak vegetative growth, enriched isotope MeHg and inorganic mercury tracers are injected at the mm scale into rhizosphere soil, guided by oxygen visualizations, to assess rates of methylation and demethylation in different redox zones. After plants complete their lifecycle, grain is collected to identify the net, integrated effect of altered root exudation or soil oxygenation on MeHg concentrations in rice grain, the endpoint most relevant to human health. This unique approach allows examination of the spatial distribution and biogeochemical drivers of MeHg production at a fine scale in an intact, living, plant-soil system. Such spatial resolution is necessary to characterize how organic carbon and oxygen enhance or diminish the net production of MeHg in the rhizosphere of rice, and thus help control MeHg contamination of rice grain. Importantly, the project directly studies mercury demethylation, an important pathway for MeHg degradation in soils, but a process that is poorly understood in comparison to mercury methylation.

por.por_cntn:
Motivation:

Rice, a staple food of more than four billion people, can be a primary route of human exposure to methylmercury (MeHg). This bioaccumulative neurotoxin can cause adverse health effects even at trace levels, making MeHg contamination of rice an issue of global public health concern. The MeHg content in rice grain originates from paddy, soil where it is both microbially formed from inorganic mercury (methylation) and degraded back to inorganic mercury (de-methylation). The relative rates of these two processes within the root zone (the rhizosphere) control MeHg concentrations and therefore plant, and human, exposure to MeHg.

Intellectual Merit:

In this project we conducted three different rice-growth experiments that advanced mechanistic understanding of factors controlling rates of methylation and de-methylation, and concentrations of MeHg in the soil-plant-grain system. Such information is needed to design and support management approaches that reduce MeHg contamination of rice grain.  

The first experiment demonstrated that rice plants altered the microbial processes that influence rates of methylation and de-methylation in soil. In soil without rice plants, the rate of methylation controlled soil MeHg concentrations (Strickman et al. 2022); when methylation rates increased, MeHg concentrations also increased. There was no clear relationship between de-methylation rates and soil MeHg concentrations in soil without plants. When rice plants were present, rates of methylation were less variable. Because of this uniformity, soil MeHg concentrations were controlled by de-methylation; when de-methylation rates increased, MeHg concentrations decreased. These results indicate that methylation and demethylation processes could both be leveraged to alter MeHg concentrations in rice soil.

The second experiment investigated the impact that elevated concentrations of carbon dioxide (ECO2) has on inorganic mercury (IHg) and MeHg concentration in rice plants. Atmospheric concentrations of carbon dioxide are increasing and hold potential to affect mercury contamination of rice. We found that ECO2 (800 ppm CO2) doubled the concentration of MeHg in rice grain relative to plants grown at ambient CO2, but did not affect IHg concentrations. Plant uptake of MeHg from soil was significantly greater in the ECO2 treatment. Our results indicate that as CO2 concentrations rise, the human health risks from IHg in rice grain are likely to remain stable, but threats related to MeHg in grain will be exacerbated.

The third experiment tested the impact that soil oxygen and organic carbon concentrations have on MeHg in the rice-soil system. The roots of rice plants release both oxygen and organic carbon into the rhizosphere; we manipulated these processes with additional oxygen and organic carbon supply. Our results indicate that oxygen reduced while organic carbon increased methylation rates and MeHg concentrations in soil. When oxygen and organic carbon were applied together, their opposing soil effects cancelled one another. These soil impacts propagated up into rice grain. In grain, carbon supply increased MeHg concentration relative to the control by 74%. When oxygen and carbon were applied together, grain MeHg concentrations were 35% lower than in the carbon-only treatment. These results highlight that choosing cultivars that release high amounts of oxygen, but low amounts of organic carbon, may reduce MeHg contamination of rice.

Broader Impacts:

The project has direct societal relevance due to its focus on rice, a staple food. Results will inform agricultural strategies that minimize MeHg contamination of rice grain by adding to the growing body of research on biogeochemical drivers of MeHg production and destruction.

Project personnel created an artistic, high-quality video that presents health hazards of MeHg in rice and other foods, introduces the MeHg cycle, and discusses factors that influence the MeHg cycle. The video is available on Youtube (https://youtu.be/dIi4mSwquP4)

The project supported a postdoctoral scientist and provided 7 undergraduate students with research experiences. Undergraduate research is a high-impact educational practice, with positive professional and personal outcomes (Lopatto 2010). Of particular note, the project assisted in the retention of women, an underrepresented group in the STEM pipeline. Although parity has been achieved in terms of undergraduate STEM degrees between women and men, representation in STEM jobs is still biased towards men (Sassler et al., 2017). This project enabled Dr. Strickman, a female scientist, to obtain a postdoctoral experience. It also provided motivation for one of the female undergraduate researchers to pursue a graduate degree in a STEM field.  

References:

Lopatto, D. Undergraduate Research as a High-Impact Student Experience. Peer Review 2010, 12.

Sassler, S.; Glass, J.; Levitte, Y.; Michelmore, K.M. The Missing Women in STEM? Assessing Gender Differentials in the Factors Associated with Transition to First Jobs. Social Science Research 2017, 63, 192?208, doi:10.1016/j.ssresearch.2016.09.014.

Strickman, R.J.; Larson, S.; Huang, H.; Kakouros, E.; Marvin-DiPasquale, M.; Mitchell, C.P.J.; Neumann, R.B. The Relative Importance of Mercury Methylation and Demethylation in Rice Paddy Soil Varies Depending on the Presence of Rice Plants. Ecotoxicology and Environmental Safety 2022, 230, 113143, doi:10.1016/j.ecoenv.2021.113143.
